Award.AwardTitle: 3rd ASM Conference on Beneficial Microbes to be held in Miami, Florida, October 25-29, 2010
Award.AbstractNarration: Research advances provide evidence that most animals and plants depend upon associations with coevolved communities of microorganisms. These consortia of beneficial microbial symbionts play critical roles in physiological balance, and partner with the host's immune system to foster health. Recognition of these phenomena is revolutionizing how biologists view the function of the normal microbiota of animals and plants. Investigation of host-microbe interactions has been enabled by recent technical advances, making this a critical time to examine research frontiers in this area. The American Society for Microbiology (ASM) has held internationally attended conferences on beneficial microbes in 2005 and 2008 that brought together biologists from a broad range of scientific disciplines. This year the conference will be held in Miami, Florida. The aim is to provide a forum for discussion and exchange of ideas, and to develop new approaches and a conceptual synthesis. This young field is attracting graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, many of whom will attend this conference. To assure a broad representation, 30% of the organizational committee are women; in addition, 7 of 21 of the invited speakers are junior (pre-tenure), and 8 of the 21 are women. Of the 39 contributed oral presentations, 18 (46%) will be selected for support from submitted abstracts, ensuring ample high-visibility for innovative investigators and ideas. As in the previous meetings, the selection process for these supported presentations will focus on junior researchers, women and minorities. Students at underrepresented minority institutions will be also targets for support. The proposal budget includes 10 travel awards for minority graduate students with US citizenship, and the awardees will be selected based on the quality of their abstracts.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report for the General Public

National Science Foundation                    

IOS-Symbiosis, Defense & Self-recognition

Awardee: ASM        Award Number: 1035909

 

This report describes the results of support provided by the National Science Foundation for the 3rd Beneficial Microbes Conference (BMC) ‘Host-Microbe Interactions in Health and Disease’, which was held October 25-29, 2010 at the Hyatt Regency Miami in Miami, Florida. The conference was an American Society for Microbiology-sponsored meeting devoted to exploring the frontier field of the role of beneficial bacteria in health and disease.

 

Conference Objective:  The primary objective of this meeting was to provide a forum for researchers in diverse fields to discuss and exchange ideas regarding the role of beneficial bacteria and other microbes in health and disease, and to consider how best the field might continue to develop as an effective discipline. A defining principle of this Conference is that the complexity and novelty of this field demands a broad array of scientific expertise to reveal the mechanisms that underlie host-microbial interactions. Thus, the Beneficial Microbes Conference (both past, current, and future) has a distinctively multidisciplinary tone.  

 

Conference Participation:  The conference had 230 registered participants, and 135 poster presentations. The conference was internationally attended: 32% of the participants were from 26 countries other than the United States; in addition, 18% were graduate students.  This latter statistic speaks strongly not only to the significant training impact of the conference, but also to the attraction that the field of beneficial microbes has for a large number of what will become the leading biologists of the future.  

     There was a broad representation among the make-up of the invited speakers. 32% of the invited speakers were junior (pre-tenure) and 27% were women. We had planned on a greater representation by women, but the withdrawal of two of our invited speakers on short notice lowered this percentage. Of the 40 total oral presentations, 18 (45%) were selected from submitted abstracts, ensuring ample high visibility for new and innovative ideas and for junior researchers to showcase their work.

 

Conference Survey Summary:  The attendees expressed very positive opinions about the conference. One third of the participants completed a survey conducted by the ASM, which can be summarized as follows: 97% said they would attend a conference on this topic again, with 79% requesting that it be offered every two years.  Approximately 97% found the speakers presentations excellent (65%) or good (32%).  The organization of the conference was rated ‘excellent’ by 72% of the survey participants, and both the instructional level (99%) and length (74%) were rated at the highest level.  On a scale of 1-10, 82% gave an 8 or higher to the statement that they would recommend this conference to a colleague.
